Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I concern that traceback is lost or not.

It is my understand that tranceback is lost.

although  traceback is output by "log.error" 
in glance log file, is it output in Jenkins result?

if my understand is incorrect, let me know.

example:
pattern A:
----------------------------------------
vagrant@precise64:~$ cat test7.py
def abc():
  a[0]

try:
  abc()
except Exception as err:
  msg="%s" % err
  raise

vagrant@precise64:~$ python test7.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test7.py", line 5, in <module>
    abc()
  File "test7.py", line 2, in abc
    a[0]
NameError: global name 'a' is not defined
----------------------------------------------

->Traceback is'nt lost.
  "abc" function is cause by trace back at a glance.

pattern B)
-------------------------------------
vagrant@precise64:~$ cat test7.py
def abc():
  a[0]

try:
  abc()
except Exception as err:
  msg="%s" % err
  raise Exception(msg)

vagrant@precise64:~$ python test7.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test7.py", line 8, in <module>
    raise Exception(msg)
Exception: global name 'a' is not defined
------------------------------------------

->Traceback is lost.
Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Noboru: Yes, what you say is correct. I'm not sure how valuable the trace back is in this situation (it's really only picking up exceptions from the fetch request against the backend) but I agree that this could be seen as an added frustration.

I don't really see an obvious way to avoid this, however.
Uploaded patch set 3.

Patch Set 4:

Hi, Thomas 

In Python 2.x,  we can get traceback by sys.exc_info()
and set third argument of raise statement. 
 - http://docs.python.org/2/reference/simple_stmts.html#raise

thanks

Example)
-------------------------------------------------
vagrant@precise64:~$ cat test7.py
import sys

class GlanceException(Exception):
    """
    Base Glance Exception

    To correctly use this class, inherit from it and define
    a 'message' property. That message will get printf'd
    with the keyword arguments provided to the constructor.
    """
    message = "test"

    def __init__(self, message=None, *args, **kwargs):
        if not message:
            message = self.message
        try:
            message = message % kwargs
        except Exception:
            if _FATAL_EXCEPTION_FORMAT_ERRORS:
                raise
            else:
                # at least get the core message out if something happened
                pass

        super(GlanceException, self).__init__(message)

def abc():
  a[0]

try:
  abc()
except Exception as err:
  t=sys.exc_info()[2]
  msg="%s" % err
  raise GlanceException(msg),None,t

vagrant@precise64:~$ python test7.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test7.py", line 31, in <module>
    abc()
  File "test7.py", line 28, in abc
    a[0]
__main__.GlanceException: global name 'a' is not defined

Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hi Thomas,

Notwithstanding the existing error logging in size_checked_iter, I don't really think size_checked_iter is the right place to be translating all Exceptions to GlanceExceptions.

I think it may make more sense to look at providing a different iterator-wrapper that does exception handling somewhere in glance/api/v1/images.py, say over here https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/api/v1/images.py#L1097

But maybe there is an even better alternative, and I just can't quite think of it. Can you provide some examples of the kinds of errors that are happening and  how they are leading to a nova hang?

Thanks!

Patch Set 5:

Hi Mark, I've added some details to the bug report for your consideration.

In regards to your other comment, are you suggesting that I wrap the iterable that is passed in to size_checked_iter? And will doing so at the location you pointed out cover us for all the relevant cases?

Thanks

Patch Set 6:

This looks like the right approach. I think it needs a little cleanup and to get tests passing, still, but I think you're on the right path.

Patch Set 6:

As for the approach in PS5, I'm wondering if this approach can work as expected when admin using a paste deploy flavor which without 'caching' wsgi middleware. Since I think the backend store still be able to raise exception like IOError, but handling code are all in caching middleware as you did in PS6.

Actually I'm try to give you move specific evidence but I can't reproduce this defect/issue in my local dev env.
Uploaded patch set 7.
